articles.title: Screen Australia Gets Behind Antarctica-Shot Drama ‘Shiver' In 46-Project Funding Round
articles.summary: Screen Australia has announced AUS$12.8 million ($7.9 million) funding round across 46 narrative projects. Robert Connolly's Shiver is the first Australian narrative feature film to shoot in Antarctica. The drama is adapted from Nikki Gemmell's novel and follows a young journalist as she ventures into the vast, fragile wilderness of Antarctica.

articles.title: If not net zero, then what?
articles.author: Bev Cornaby
articles.summary: It's getting harder to ignore the climate crisis. 2024 was the first year since pre-industrialisation where global surface temperatures rose above zero degrees Celsius.  The world needs to act now to prevent a global warming crisis.   The climate crisis is getting worse.

articles.title: New research uncovers key culprit behind accelerating global threat: 'An increasingly dominant role'
articles.author: Matthew Swigonski
articles.summary: New research uncovers key culprit behind accelerating global threat: "An increasingly dominant role" in driving global sea-level rise. Sea level rise has already begun to wreak havoc on coastal communities around the world. Many efforts to address sea level rise have focused on mitigation, especially the attempt to reduce gas pollution.

articles.title: WEF's climate alarm
articles.author: News Desk
articles.summary: The World Economic Forum report warns that climate change could result in 14.5 million excess deaths and trillions of dollars in economic losses by 2050. According to the WEF, deaths from extreme weather events in disadvantaged regions have already been about fifteen times higher in the past decade. Less than five percent of global adaptation funding currently goes toward health protection. Pakistan witnesses climate-induced disasters each year.

articles.title: The climate crisis may also be a ticking financial time bomb
articles.author: David Fogarty
articles.summary: Bankers and corporate CEOs are struggling to manage growing financial risks. Climate change is weakening growth, swelling debt and creating shocks with cascading effects. The seeds of the next financial crisis have already been sown and will be driven by climate change, says ST.

articles.title: "Ten Feet Of Water Coming": Antarctica Collapses Faster Than Expected While Scientists Watch Emperor Penguins Die
articles.author: Hina Dinoo
articles.summary: Scientists warn of rapid transformations in Antarctica's climate with potential global impacts. The collapse of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet could lead to a significant sea level rise. Wildlife in Antarctica, including emperor penguins, faces growing risks due to ecological changes. Urgent action is required to address the interconnected environmental shifts and prevent irreversible damage.

articles.title: Extinctions Are Slowing, Not Speeding Toward Mass Catastrophe After All
articles.author: Studyfinds Analysis
articles.summary: Since 1500, only 102 genera of plants and animals have gone extinct worldwide. Most extinctions happened on islands, often due to invasive species. Extinctions peaked in the late 1800s and early 1900s, then declined. Conservation efforts have helped prevent further losses for birds and mammals.

articles.title: Natural disasters
articles.author: Muhammad Zahid Rifat
articles.summary: Floods are the most destructive natural disaster in Pakistan. Extreme temperatures are emerging as an ever-deadlier threat. The most catastrophic flooding in Pakistan's history had occurred in 2010 when the country experienced extraordinary rainfall. One third of the country had gone underwater and 33 million people were affected. In 2022, the damage was estimated at US $ 14.9 billion and the loss to the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) was US $ 15.2 billion. Pakistan has a National Climate Change Policy.

articles.title: Climate activists rally around the world in 'Draw the line' march
articles.summary: World leaders are gathering in New York this week for the 80th session of the United Nations General Assembly. In the Pacific climate activists have been rallying to demand greater climate action from world leaders. 350.org campaigner Jacynta Fa'amau is disappointed with Australia's recent announcement on fossil fuel emissions reduction targets.

articles.title: The Oldest And Coldest Ice Core Samples In The World Are About To Help Us Fight The Climate Crisis
articles.author: Kyra Piperides
articles.summary: The Beyond EPICA – Oldest Ice project has retrieved ice cores from East Antarctica that date back 1.5 million years. The analysis of the ice cores will bring our understanding of climate history forward leaps and bounds thanks to the precise techniques that ice allows. The project is driven by a central scientific question: why did the planet's climate cycle shift roughly one million years ago?

articles.title: Extreme weather is forcing investors to rethink how to manage physical climate risks
articles.author: Jeffrey Jones ESG
articles.summary: Investors are wrestling with increasing climate-related physical risks within their vast portfolios. The world is on track for a 3.1-degree increase in global temperatures by the end of the century. The insurance industry is responding by raising premiums, tightening policy terms and withdrawing coverage.

articles.title: With 2035 emissions targets set, what Australia does next will help shape global efforts to keep 1.5°C alive
articles.author: Rebecca Burdon
articles.summary: This week, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese will attend the United Nations General Assembly meeting in New York. He will present Australia's new 2035 emission cut target of 62–70% on 2005 levels. UN Secretary General António Guterres invited global leaders to present their new targets for 2035. The UN is hoping more ambitious 2035 targets will build momentum for the COP30 climate talks in Brazil in November.

articles.title: Glacier Melting: Global And Indian Perspective Author: Dr. Md Jawaid E
articles.summary: Glaciers are crucial for Earth's climate system and human life. The rate of glacier melting has accelerated due to global temperature rise and human activities. Timely policies and measures are essential to prevent glacier melting. The recommendations are: Reducing greenhouse gas emissions, forest conservation, reforestation, monitoring, and education.

articles.title: Nilafar's Desert Crossing: Avignon 2025
articles.author: Sophie Lin
articles.summary: The study of deserts is becoming central to understanding and navigating the 21st century's most pressing challenges. Deserts are dynamic archives of climate history, offering crucial data for predicting future climate scenarios. Anthropologists argue that deserts have always been vital crossroads of trade, migration and cultural exchange. Cécile Fromont's research on engravings and sacred mountains from Angola to Tuscany demonstrates a deep-rooted spiritual connection between humans and arid landscapes.

articles.title: Africa & Climate Justice: Demands for Global Action
articles.summary: Africa is warming faster than the global average and 2024 will be the warmest year on record. Seven of the ten most climate-vulnerable nations are located in Africa. Over 200 million Africans have already been impacted by extreme weather in the last five years. Water scarcity, declining yields, and rising plant diseases threaten food security for millions. Ethiopia's Green Legacy Initiative (GLI) is an example of large-scale climate adaptation.

articles.title: Albanese takes his usual each-way bet on climate change
articles.author: Ross Gittins
articles.summary: Anthony Albanese and his Climate Change Minister Chris Bowen fooled people into thinking they are doing something to fix a problem when in fact they're doing more to make it worse than make it better. The Paris climate change agreement of 2015 committed Australia to reduce its emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gasses by 43 per cent of their 2005 level by 2030. Last week the target was raised to between 62 per cent and 70 per cent.

articles.title: Albanese takes his usual each-way bet on climate change
articles.author: Ross Gittins
articles.summary: Anthony Albanese and his Climate Change Minister Chris Bowen are doing a poor job of protecting our children and grandchildren's future. Last week they released an official report and set a target to do insufficient to stop global warming over the decade to 2035. They did it by waving around % signs.

articles.title: Not just a haven for ‘Western refugees'; we could be a global power
articles.author: Sydney Morning Herald
articles.summary: Australia has become a popular destination for people fleeing Trump, Brexit and the politics of Marine Le Pen. Australia has the potential to be so much more than it is today, says the author of the book "Australia: A Journey into the Heart of the Land"

articles.title: 18-million-year-old songbird ancestor fossil discovered at famous Australian site
articles.author: Interesting Engineering
articles.summary: A fossil of a 17-18 million-year-old bird has been discovered at Riversleigh, in northwest Queensland, Australia. Riversleigh is one of the world's premier fossil sites. The fossil has strong ties to Australia's most iconic species of songbird.

articles.title: Zero to Three Children Movement for Earth and Beyond Wealth
articles.author: Jarga Kebba Gigo
articles.summary: There are more than 100 billion people on the Earth and they are increasing due to population growth. There are four main concerns: Angering the Lord with indifference, a catastrophic interplanetary intervention, wars over land, diseases and other disasters and sub-quality life to children.

articles.title: Does Boolaroo's former smelter site need to become a fast-food hub?
articles.author: Letters to the Editor
articles.summary: The Griffith Group is planning a fast-food restaurant in Boolaroo. A UKUS nuclear submarine base is planned for Newcastle and Port Kembla. Jacinta Nampijinpa Price's comments on Indian population voting Labor were wrong. Jacqui Daley, chair of Hunter Manufacturing, forgot to mention one of the biggest industries in the area was shipbuilding and ship repair.

articles.title: 18-million-year-old bird fossil shows roots of Australia's songbirds
articles.author: Maria Mocerino
articles.summary: A fossil of a 17-18 million-year-old Lyrebird-like species has been found at Riversleigh, in northwest Queensland, Australia. It belonged to Menura tyawanoides, a ground-dwelling bird that lived millions of years ago in the lowland tropical rainforests.

articles.title: Researchers study effects of shrinking snowpack in New England
articles.author: Marion Umpleby
articles.summary: The average amount of snow that accumulates on the ground throughout the winter season, or snowpack, is shrinking from year to year across the Northeast. Many who live and recreate in the region have noticed it in their own lives. Emerson Conrad-Rooney grew up cross-country skiing with his family in Massachusetts. Eric Kelsey grew up an enthusiastic winter recreator in Nashua. Kelsey and David Zywiczynski are working on a 'snow drought index' that may be the first tool of its kind in the nation.

articles.title: Expert debunks Joe Rogan's disturbing false claim from recent podcast: 'You can see how big a problem we're dealing with'
articles.author: Margaret Wong
articles.summary: Expert debunks Joe Rogan's false claim from recent podcast: 'You can see how big a problem we're dealing with' According to meteorologist Chris Gloninger, Earth has always cycled between glacial and interglacial periods. The warming we've seen since the Industrial Revolution has happened in less than two centuries.

articles.title: Iranian, European officials to meet in Vienna as sanctions reimposition looms
articles.summary: Australia, Canada and UK recognize Palestinian state. PMW urges UN to halt Palestine recognition until PA reforms. Greta Thunberg removed from Gaza flotilla leadership. Israel should annex the West Bank, but not now, according to PMW and MKs.

articles.title: The Independent Climate 100 List 2025
articles.author: The Independent
articles.summary: This year the UK had its hottest spring and summer since records began in 1884. Florida just had the worst drought in 24 years and the LA fires displaced thousands. Abi Daré's novel And So I Roar documents how the climate crisis also triggers social crisis in rural Nigerian communities. Canadian photographer Edward Burtynsky uses his lens to powerfully track humanity's disastrous environmental footprint.

articles.title: Solar farm plans could help revive the Gwent Levels
articles.summary: The Gwent Levels are a Site of Special Scientific Interest (SSSI) in Wales. Climate change and intensive farming are two major threats to the SSSI. Farmers are under financial pressure due to rising energy and fuel costs. The proposed Craig Y Perthi solar farm would replace low-diversity monocultures with rich habitats free from chemicals and tailored to the needs of wildlife.

articles.title: Hurricane Helene hit North Carolina a year ago. Some students never returned to school
articles.author: MAKIYA SEMINERA
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene destroyed 73,000 homes in North Carolina. Thousands of students lost their homes. More than 2,500 students were identified as homeless as a direct result of Helene. Many families in rural, low-income areas don't get the opportunity to recover.

articles.title: Hurricane Helene hit North Carolina a year ago. Some students never returned to school
articles.author: MAKIYA SEMINERA
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene destroyed 73,000 homes in North Carolina. Thousands of students lost their homes. More than 2,500 students were identified as homeless as a direct result of Helene. Many families in rural, low-income areas don't get the opportunity to recover.

articles.title: Marseille mosque shut down due to alleged ties to Muslim Brotherhood
articles.author: MATHILDA HELLER
articles.summary: Australia, Canada and UK recognize Palestinian state. PMW urges UN to halt Palestine recognition until PA reforms. Palestinian FM says recognition brings independence closer. Greta Thunberg removed from Gaza flotilla leadership. Israel should annex the West Bank, but not now.

articles.title: Season of Disaster: Downpours and Heatwaves Becoming the Norm as Japanese Summers Get Hotter and Longer
articles.author: Tachibana Yoshihiro
articles.summary: July 2025 was the hottest July on record in Japan, averaging 2.89° Celsius above normal for the month. Tanba in Hyōgo set an all-time national high of 41.2° on July 30. Isesaki in Gunma surpassed the mark a week later at 41.8°. High-seas research tracked the rise in ocean temperatures off the Pacific coast of Tōhoku.

articles.title: Forecasters Monitoring Tropical Wave with Medium Development Chance
articles.author: Kartik Krishnaiyer
articles.summary: The National Hurricane Center is monitoring a broad tropical wave that is moving through the central tropical Atlantic. Forecasters say conditions could become more favorable for development later this week. The wave has a 40 percent chance of forming into a tropical depression within the next seven days. Residents are advised to monitor the progress of the system and make hurricane preparedness plans.

articles.title: Portland Rain Returns: Fall Forecast After Sunny Weekend ☔️
articles.summary: There will be a break in the Oregon-Oregon State rivalry between the Oregon Ducks and the Oregon State Beavers for at least a year due to changing weather patterns. The Pacific Northwest is known for its variable weather, but the intensity and frequency of shifts is accelerating due to climate change. The economic consequences of these disruptions are substantial and the need for adaptation is urgent.

articles.title: Local View: Don't let Northland 'paradise' fool you on climate change
articles.summary: Russ Mattson lives in Paradise, Michigan, 315 miles from the center of the continent on the eastern end of Lake Superior. It was 42 degrees in Two Harbors the morning he started writing this. The rest of the world is seeing searing heat, droughts, floods, and wildfires caused by climate change.

articles.title: Chinese sparrowhawk presence over Kenting sets all-time record
articles.author: Enditem/ls
articles.summary: More than 150,000 Chinese sparrowhawks were recorded flying over Kenting in southern Taiwan's Pingtung County on Saturday. The Hengchun Peninsula is the last part of Taiwan that migratory birds and raptors fly over as they head from East Asia to wintering grounds in Southeast Asia and Indonesia.

articles.title: Storm Alerts: Provinces Affected This Sunday ⚠️
articles.summary: Extreme weather events are increasing in frequency and intensity across Argentina due to climate change. Argentina experienced a 30% increase in climate-related disaster declarations over the past decade. The economic consequences of these escalating weather events can be substantial. Argentina's agricultural sector, cornerstone of the national economy, is particularly vulnerable.

articles.title: Could wildfire smoke become America's leading climate health threat by 2050?
articles.author: The Los Angeles Times
articles.summary: Ash and soot from burning wildlands has caused more than 41,000 excess deaths annually from 2011 to 2020, according to new research. By 2050, as global warming makes large swaths of North America hotter and drier, the annual death toll could reach 100,000.

articles.title: Earth's pole might flip anytime! Here's how you can save yourself during calamity
articles.summary: Thomas's calculations suggest that Earth is overdue for a pole flip by thousands of years. Mainstream science does not support rapid pole shifts, but the theory warns of potential global-scale calamities if such an event occurs. Thomas's calculations are not supported by mainstream science.

articles.title: Dozens died in Birmingham from 2025 summer heatwaves
articles.author: Jordan Coussins
articles.summary: At least 1,147 people died in the UK this summer due to heatwaves caused by human-induced global warming, including 52 in Birmingham. The study was carried out by 11 researchers from Imperial College London, the London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine, the Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute and Copenhagen University of Tropical Medicine.

articles.title: Overdevelopment played big part in Milwaukee flood damage, not climate alone
articles.author: Letters to the Editor
articles.summary: There has been a "1000-year flood" in Pewaukee, New Hampshire. Overdevelopment and the current administration's failure to support initiatives designed to combat it are the main reasons for the problem. Steve Smith offers some tips to get your views shared with your friends and family.

articles.title: Give robins, bluetits and blackbirds one food in Sept says RSPB
articles.author: newsdesk@devonlive.com
articles.summary: September is a quieter time of year for birds as they are moulting and the mating season is over. The RSPB recommends feeding them high-energy, high-fat foods during cold weather. It's started to get colder in September and people need to consider that birds need greater energy.

articles.title: We're in danger of forgetting Trump's worst crime of all
articles.author: Tom Tyner
articles.summary: Donald Trump is a climate change denier. He has been bought and paid for by the oil industry. The US is the second largest emitter of greenhouse gases in the world. Trump is increasing the output of the biggest CO2 emitters in the US by gutting federal regulations.

articles.title: Now is time for climate action
articles.summary: Wildsight Invermere and 34 partner organizations remind BC to align its climate policies with both international and Canadian law. The International Court of Justice ruled that governments are legally obligated to protect the environment from GHG emissions. Now is the time to push BC to live up to its obligations.

articles.title: Australia must do more to end Gaza war says author of ‘genocide' report
articles.author: Nicola Smith
articles.summary: The recognition of Palestinian statehood is a 'very significant step' but Australia must do more to help end the conflict in Gaza, says the author of a UN report that alleged Israel is committing genocide. More than 65,000 people have been killed in the conflict.

articles.title: 5786 – Our Last Chance to Avert a Climate Catastrophe?
articles.author: Richard H. Schwartz
articles.summary: The world is on the verge of a climate catastrophe. Every decade since the 1970s has been hotter than the previous decade. All 25 years in this century are among the 26 hottest years in recorded history. The 13 consecutive months from June 2023 to June 24 all broke monthly temperature records. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) warned that 'unprecedented changes' were needed by 2030 to avert a catastrophe. Israel is especially threatened by climate change. A shift toward plant-based diets is the only approach that significantly reduces greenhouse gas emissions.

articles.title: The Florida Climate Forecast Conference is returning to the Suncoast in November
articles.author: Ella Thompson
articles.summary: The fifth annual Florida Climate Forecast Conference will take place on Nov. 13 at the Selby Auditorium on the University of South Florida's Sarasota-Manatee campus. The morning session will focus on climate and biodiversity through the last ice age. The midday sessions will discuss how climate change is reshaping Florida's ecosystems, as well as warming and rising seas.

articles.title: Maine summers haven't lost their magic
articles.author: Deb Sayer
articles.summary: This is in response to the column 'Are Maine summers losing their magic?' by Leslie Bridgers (Sept. 7). The points made in the column were factual, but do not tell the whole story of what a Maine summer is like. This summer had a record-breaking heat wave in Portland, but the average temperature in the area was still around 70 degrees Fahrenheit.

articles.title: Stars Gettin' Lit By The Fireplace -- Bring The Heat!
articles.author: TMZ
articles.summary: Celebrities have been spending time by the fire this winter. Kourtney Kardashian, Flea, Hailey Bieber, and Alexandra Daddario have been showing off how to do it this season.    -      for this article.

articles.title: Climate change crusaders call for debt cancellation
articles.author: Franca Ochigbo
articles.summary: Dr. David Terungwa has called for the cancellation of debt for Nigeria and other African countries for loans collected to fund mitigation and adaptation even though the funding for mitigation is much more than the one for adaptation. Gloria Agema of the Gee Foundation described the Social and Health Impact Assessment Bill before the National Assembly as a forward-looking reform.

articles.title: Love our forests
articles.author: Ian McDonald
articles.summary: Almost all of the Indian Ocean's coral reefs have died in recent years. The coral expels organisms that live in the hard limestone core and cannot tolerate a rise in sea temperature of over 1-20 degrees Celsius. The heat dome which had settled over Guyana in 2023 tells me the inconvenient truth.

articles.title: Greenpeace USA Unveils Giant 'Bill' With Expected Economic Damages From Just 5 Major Oil & Gas Companies At NYC
articles.author: Independent Media Institute
articles.summary: Greenpeace USA activists deployed a giant 'Climate Polluters Bill' nearly 160 feet long through midtown Manhattan today. They were marching in a mass demonstration during Climate Week NYC and on the eve of the UN General Assembly and the UN Secretary General's Climate Ambition Summit. The bill reveals that economic damages from carbon dioxide (CO) emissions of five major oil and gas corporations throughout 2016-25 are projected to amount to over US$ 5 trillion. This is 7000 times greater than the amount countries have pledged to the UN's fund for loss and damage.

articles.title: Brace for chill: How La Nina will bring harsh winter, severe cold to India
articles.summary: After heavy monsoons, India is bracing for a colder-than-average winter this year due to La Nina conditions. La Nina is a climate phenomenon characterised by unusually cold sea surface temperatures in the Equatorial Pacific Ocean. It is part of the El Nio-Southern Oscillation cycle, which alternates between the cooling and warming of Pacific waters. It's expected to benefit Indian agriculture through enhanced monsoon rains in 2025, but it raises concerns about extreme cold waves.

articles.title: A history of intrigue and controversy: Rupert Darwall's 'The Age of Global Warming'
articles.author: Tags
articles.summary: The environmental movement gained momentum in the 1960s with Rachel Carson's "Silent Spring" and the 1972 Stockholm Conference. The 1980s saw a resurgence of environmentalism with Margaret Thatcher's support and the establishment of the IPCC in 1988. The 1990s emphasized sustainable development, culminating in the 1992 Rio Earth Summit and the 1997 Kyoto Protocol. The Kyoto Protocol's exemption of developing nations from emission reduction targets led to its rejection by the United States. The IPCC's reports, including the controversial "Hockey Stick" graph, have faced scrutiny, revealing rifts within the scientific community.

articles.title: Higher CO2 uptake in once-colder regions hasn't slowed global warming
articles.author: Junya Iwai
articles.summary: Despite widespread forest loss from logging and wildfires, overall carbon dioxide absorption has risen as warmer temperatures stimulate plant growth in colder climates. July 21, 2025 13:09 JST is the date of Japan's independence from the Soviet Union and the beginning of the 20th century.

articles.title: Australia's Climate Challenge: A Balancing Act of Hope and Action
articles.author: smh
articles.summary: Australia faces a huge challenge in meeting its 2035 emissions targets. The first National Climate Risk Assessment predicts the consequences of inaction. The Montreal Protocol, the first universally ratified treaty in United Nations history, is an example of how scientific advancements, international cooperation, and dedicated effort can reverse environmental damage. The widespread use of DDT is a cautionary tale of environmental impacts and the importance of regulation.

articles.title: Global warming and increased travel drive surge in Hong Kong dengue infections
articles.author: South China Morning Post
articles.summary: Global warming and globalisation have increased the number of imported dengue fever cases in Hong Kong, health experts say. Annual infections are also rising, according to the experts. The number of cases is on the rise due to global warming and the rise of globalisation.

articles.title: Experts issue warning after observing alarming shift in great white shark behavior: 'Something we have to accept'
articles.author: Matthew Marini
articles.summary: Great white shark sightings in northern New England waters have increased recently. The number of great whites detected off Canadian coasts has more than doubled from 2018 to 2022. The first recorded shark fatality in Maine happened in 2020 when a great white killed a 63-year-old off Bailey Island. Government agencies, researchers and conservation groups are working to protect sharks and safeguard people.

articles.title: Here's the good news: we've improved the environment before, and we can do it again
articles.author: Sydney Morning Herald
articles.summary: The predictions of Australia's climate future if we fail to act are bleak. But we've done it before and we'll do it again if we don't change our ways.    i.e. if we do not act on climate change we will be worse off.

articles.title: Varied Causes Unite Against Profits
articles.author: Newser Editors
articles.summary: Thousands of activists marched in New York on Saturday to "Make Billionaires Pay" in support of climate justice, democracy, free speech, gender equality, a stop to the Trump administration's immigration enforcement, and a ceasefire in Gaza. Tamika Middleton of the Women's March said this year's march highlighted the intersections between environmental, economic and immigrant issues.

articles.title: Signs of Climate Change: Predictions for the Mediterranean Region's Future Based on Current Trends and Impacts
articles.author: Dr. Priya Deshmukh
articles.summary: The Mediterranean basin is warming at a rate 20% higher than the global average. The Bay of Valsaline in Croatia is experiencing a dramatic shift in it's ecosystem, transitioning from a vibrant and diverse surroundings to one threatened by loss of habitat and invasive species. The Mediterranean is already a water-stressed region, and climate change is worsening the situation.

articles.title: Stony Brook University-led study finds wildfire smoke could lead to tens of thousands of deaths
articles.author: Newsday
articles.summary: There will be more wildfires due to climate change factors in the coming decades. Their smoke could lead to tens of thousands of deaths by 2050, according to a new study led by a Stony Brook University researcher. The impact could be felt locally, although wildfires themselves are not a major issue in the area.

articles.title: A walk across Alaska's Arctic sea ice brings to life the losses that appear in climate data
articles.author: Newsgram Desk
articles.summary: As a polar climate scientist, he has been working on Arctic sea ice for over a decade. He visited Utqiagvik, Alaska, and spent time with local people who rely on the sea ice. The local hunters run snowmobiles over the ice to reach the whales and seals they rely on for their traditional food. They describe worsening coastal erosion as the protective ice disappears earlier and forms later.

articles.title: Andrew Hastie is fighting the climate war like Tony Abbott
articles.author: Lidija Ivanovski
articles.summary: A Labor government is riding high in the polls and wants to impress at an upcoming international climate conference. The Coalition is looking hopelessly divided on the issue of climate change and its moderate leader is looking increasingly isolated on the matter of emissions reduction. The party is looking for a leader who is more committed to the cause.

articles.title: 2-day training workshop on climate change in Chitral
articles.author: Shah Murad Baig
articles.summary: The Pakistan Red Crescent Society (PRCS) Khyber Pakhtunkhwa organized a two-day training workshop to build awareness among volunteers and staff members on the basics of climate change. A total of 20 young people under the age of 30, including 13 men and seven women from Chitral district took part in the training.

articles.title: Call for next steps to back 'ambitious' emissions goal
articles.author: Kat Wong
articles.summary: "We need to be part of a global effort to reduce the amount of carbon that we put into the atmosphere to stop or limit global warming so that we can protect our lives and our livelihoods," he says.       .

articles.title: Call for next steps to back 'ambitious' emissions goal
articles.author: Kat Wong
articles.summary: The minister in charge of Australia's climate change policy is facing questions over a new renewable energy goal. Australia is under pressure to back its controversial climate target with action.   for the new renewable power goal. articles.title: Climate change may devastate millions of lives, economy by 2050: WEF
articles.author: Amin Ahmed
articles.summary: Climate change could result in 14.5 million excess deaths and $1.5 trillion in economic loses by 2050, mainly in the world's most disadvantaged regions and populations. Less than 5 per cent of global adaptation funding targets health protection. Health and health-care sector is expected to face at least $200 billion in worker-availability losses between 2025 and 2050. Construction workers are particularly vulnerable.

articles.title: 70,000 Americans could die every year from wildfire smoke by 2050, study warns
articles.author: The Economic Times
articles.summary: There could be 70,000 wildfire-related deaths per year in the US by 2050, according to a new study. This is an escalating trend.      Â   .   in the study by the University of California, Los Angeles.

articles.title: Climate change may devastate millions of lives, economy by 2050: WEF
articles.author: Dawn
articles.summary: Climate change could result in 14.5 million excess deaths, mainly in vulnerable regions. Health, construction and agriculture sectors could lose over $1.5tr due to climate change, according to World Economic Forum report. It is titled "Building Economic Resilience to the Health Impacts of Climate Change".

articles.title: Column: Global warming's strain on your eyes
articles.author: Keith Anderson APG
articles.summary: Pauline Mercy asks EarthTalk about the link between global warming and eye problems for humans. Rising global temperatures, worsening air quality, shifting disease patterns and increasing water scarcity are contributing factors to increasing eye-related problems worldwide. Wearing sunglasses that block ultraviolet rays and reducing exposure to polluted air can lessen irritation and disease risk.

articles.title: Heat Wave
articles.author: Brain Teasers
articles.summary: Change COLD to HEAT by changing one letter at a time. Each change must produce a valid word in the English language. The solution is COLD, COOL, WOOL, WARM, HARD, and HARD.  Heats can't be used more than once.

articles.title: Okanagan Nature Nut: Falling for the wonders of a new season
articles.author: Roseanne Van Ee
articles.summary: September is a great time for Okanagan wildlife to migrate, estivate or spawn. All hummingbirds should be taken down by mid August. Great blue herons are dispersing to various open-water lakes for the winter. Kokanee salmon spawn on Coldstream Creek in late September to early October.

articles.title: Egrets gather at Poyang Lake before migration
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: Tens of thousands of egrets have gathered in Poyang Lake in east China's Jiangxi Province. The lake is a key global habitat for migratory birds. Summer migrant birds begin returning south after autumn and come back again next spring.   .

articles.title: Greta Thunberg removed from flotilla leadership amid infighting
articles.author: Israel Hayom
articles.summary: The ships of the "largest ever" flotilla to Gaza – dubbed "Sumud" are sailing toward Gaza's shores. More than 40 vessels have passed Malta and six additional ships are waiting in Greece. The major drama unfolded among the crew members, including climate activist Greta.

articles.title: Doorstop - New York (Prime Minister of Australia)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: Anthony Abbanese is representing Australia at the United Nations this week. It's the first time he's been there as Prime Minister. It is an opportunity to advance Australia's economic, national security and environmental interests. Climate change is a major concern for Abbbanese.

articles.title: Reversing Antarctic sea ice loss depends on ocean layering, study finds
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Satellite observations have documented a decline in Antarctic sea ice extent since 2014. The extent of sea ice depends on how much carbon dioxide we emit and how stratified the Southern Ocean is, according to the new research.      Â

articles.title: Southern Illinois road closes to allow 20-plus snake species to cross. Here's how to see it.
articles.author: The Pantagraph
articles.summary: The snakes are most active in their movement when high temperatures are around 70 to 80 degrees and the low temperatures at night hover in the 50s.       "Snakes are active when the temperature is around 70-80 degrees and low temperatures are 50-50 degrees."
